title: Stephen Salerno
text:
Hello, my name is


Stephen Salerno

I am a postdoctoral fellow in Biostatistics at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, working with Jeff Leek. I received my PhD and MS in Biostatistics from the University of Michigan under the supervision of Yi Li, and a BS in Biometry and Statistics from Cornell University. My research focuses on statistical methods for drawing inference on algorithmically derived variables, deep learning for high-dimensional data, and survival analysis, as well as clinical quality measures and health policy. I’m also passionate about data-for-good initiatives.









My Research At a Glance






flowchart LR
  A[Deep Learning for Prediction]\n  B[Predicted Outcomes]\n  C[Downstream Inference on Predicted Data]

Hello, my name is


Stephen Salerno
I am a postdoctoral fellow in Biostatistics at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, working with Jeff Leek. I received my PhD and MS in Biostatistics from the University of Michigan under the supervision of Yi Li. I obtained a BS in Biometry and Statistics with a minor in Health Policy from Cornell University.
My research focuses on statistical methods for drawing inference on algorithmically derived variables, deep learning approaches for high dimensional data, and survival analysis, as well as clinical quality measure development, public reporting efforts, and health policy surrounding kidney diseases and lung cancer. … User-friendly software… I am also passionate about applying my skill set to public service and am active in data for good initiatives.








My Research At a Glance

View CV{target=“_blank”}



Research Overview
I focus on three main areas:
Survey Methods: Stratified and cluster sampling inference, bias correction, variance estimation.
Post-Prediction Inference: Methods like PPI, PPI++, PSPA for valid downstream analysis of predicted data.
Deep Learning in R: Custom frameworks using torch, transformer architectures, and model interpretability.
Learn more about each area and see my published work below.



Test 3

title: Welcome!
Software
text:
galah
{galah} is an R and Python interface to biodiversity data hosted by the Atlas of Living Australia (ALA). It enables users to locate and download species occurrence records (observations, specimens, eDNA records, etc.), taxonomic information, or associated media such as images or sounds, and to restrict their queries to particular taxa or locations.  Visit the {galah} website to learn more about how to use {galah} If you have any questions, comments, or spot any bugs, email us or report an issue on the R package GitHub page or the Python package Github page










  


potions
{potions} makes options management in R—usually edited using base::options() and related functions—as easy as possible. It uses a minimalist workflow to store and retrieve information with three core functions: brew(), pour() and drain().  Visit the {potions} website to learn more about how to use {potions} If you have any questions, comments, or spot any bugs, email us or report an issue on our GitHub page

title: scorcher: Blazing a trail for effortless model building with torch in R
text:
Culex (Culex) sitiens (Nick Lambert CC BY NC SA 3.0)


Citation


Furlong, M., Adamu, A. M., Hoskins, A., Russell, T. L., Gummow, B., Golchin, M., Hickson, R. I., & Horwood, P. F. (2023) Japanese Encephalitis Enzootic and Epidemic Risks across Australia. Viruses https://doi.org/10.3390/v15020450



Page info
Prepared by Jeff Leek, Stephen Salerno





Japanese encephalitis virus is a blood-borne virus spread via mosquitos. It is often considered a rural disease, present in animal populations (often pigs and waterbirds) and able to infect humans that interact closely with animal hosts. Urbanisation and agricultural production can increase the risk that humans contract the virus.
Until recently Japanese encephalitis was thought to be geographically restricted to Northern Australia, but in 2022, it was found across all the eastern states of Australia and declared nationally significant.
Furlong and others (2023) used ALA data to obtain occurrence records of both mosquitos and waterbirds. Using ecological niche models, they found the highest risk of human exposure to the virus in coastal Australia—sprawling across the Great Dividing Range and the Murray-Darling Basin. The authors predict that Japanese encephalitis will establish an endemic circulation in Australia, increasing risks to human health.

Page info
Prepared by Jeff Leek, Stephen Salerno





Japanese encephalitis virus is a blood-borne virus spread via mosquitos. It is often considered a rural disease, present in animal populations (often pigs and waterbirds) and able to infect humans that interact closely with animal hosts. Urbanisation and agricultural production can increase the risk that humans contract the virus.
Until recently Japanese encephalitis was thought to be geographically restricted to Northern Australia, but in 2022, it was found across all the eastern states of Australia and declared nationally significant.
Furlong and others (2023) used ALA data to obtain occurrence records of both mosquitos and waterbirds. Using ecological niche models, they found the highest risk of human exposure to the virus in coastal Australia—sprawling across the Great Dividing Range and the Murray-Darling Basin. The authors predict that Japanese encephalitis will establish an endemic circulation in Australia, increasing risks to human health.

title: extra
text:
Stephen Salerno
I am a post-doctoral research fellow in the Fred Hutch Data Science Lab. My research centers on statistical methods for multivariate data and machine learning for high dimensional survival analysis, as well as its applications to clinical quality measure development, public reporting efforts, and health policy surrounding kidney diseases and lung cancer. I am also passionate about applying my skill set to public service and am active in data for good initiatives at the University of Michigan and beyond.
Education:  PhD | Biostatistics | University of Michigan | 2023  MS | Biostatistics | University of Michigan | 2018  BS | Biometry & Statistics | Cornell University | 2016 
Experience:  Post-Doctoral Research Fellow | Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center | Seattle, WA

View Login Register








Introduction to the SRE Database
This website provides an atlas of cancer synergistic regulatory enhancer networks across different organ tissues. Designed for researchers and professionals, our platform offers an interactive, data-driven resource for exploring detailed tissue-specific data, including biosample metadata, experiment summaries, and genomic regulatory elements. Dive into organ- and tissue-specific pages, where you can explore curated data, conduct track selection, and visualize results in a genome browser to advance your research.





Organ and Tissue Selection
Please select an available organ/tissue to view the related experimental data.














Announcements
Stay updated with the latest news and find more …







Documentation
Find resources and documentation on using the SRE Database.
Learn More!
